translation: Good afternoon, everyone.
transcript: 大家下午好。

translation: I’m Shen Yidong from Shanghai Institute of Biochemistry and Cell Biology, CAS.
transcript: 呃我是来自于中科院生化细胞所的沈义栋。

translation: I’m very glad to have this opportunity in sharing my idea of aging, and this idea is from the perspective of a scientist of modern biology.
transcript: 今天下午很高兴能够有机会和大家聊一聊现代生物学对于衰老的看法。

translation: I think that almost everyone is interested with the topic of aging.
transcript: 衰老，一定是每一个人啊都感兴趣的一个问题。

translation: I think it is one of the oldest scientific problems.
transcript: 它也是古今中外，啊我可以认为是最古老的科学问题之一呢。

translation: In China, a long time ago there were legends like the God of Longevity and the Magic Peaches offered as a birthday present.
transcript: 在我们国家,在很早以前，就有像寿星、寿桃这样子的传说。

translation: It was the same in the Europe.
transcript: 在欧洲也是一样。

translation: People believed that there must be a pool of youth, where you could become younger as long as you jump in and take a bath there.
transcript: 他们相信会有一个青春池，你人跳下去洗个澡，然后就可以恢复年轻。

translation: These were only utopian dreams.
transcript: 但这些都是所谓的梦想。

translation: This is the curve of a change in the average life expectancy of people across the world in the past hundreds of years.
transcript: 这是近几百年来，就是说全世界人类平均预期寿命的一个变化的曲线。

translation: We can tell that in the past few hundreds of years, especially with the advancement of industrialization, we have made huge progress in making this dream come true.
transcript: 我们可以看到在近几百年来，随着工业化的进展，在这个梦想上，我们已经获得了很大的进步。

translation: In the past the average life expectancy was only 20 to 30 years old, but now it is 70 to 80 years old.
transcript: 呃大家的平均预期寿命已经从只有二三十岁，到现在啊可以有七八十岁。

translation: For some developed countries, the figure will even reach nearly 90 years old.
transcript: 在一些发达国家甚至可以已经接近90岁，呃。

translation: What is the role of modern science behind this process?
transcript: 那么在这过程中，现代的科学做了一些什么？

translation: There is one thing that you might find it least expected, that is we have built a basic and modern health system.
transcript: 第一件事情是大家现在可能根本想不到的，就是建立了一个很近代的、很基础的卫生体系。

translation: To put it simply, many developed countries at that time had had taken measures to ensure that each household would have a flush toilet and be able to use running water.
transcript: 说的通俗一点就是，在当时的一些西方的发达国家，保证每家每户可以有抽水马桶，可以有自来水。

translation: People were advised not to dump rubbish indiscriminately and a modern waste collection system had been set up.
transcript: 啊垃圾不能乱扔，有现代化的垃圾收集设施。

translation: This was the first step.
transcript: 啊这是第一步。

translation: It was an effective step to prevent the large-scale outbreak of infectious diseases.
transcript: 它的这一点的确防止了很多大规模的疫情的发生。

translation: Secondly, in the 1940s, antibiotic was invented, and you might be very familiar with this part of history.
transcript: 然后第二个就是上世纪四五十年代，这点可能大家比较熟悉，这个主要是抗生素的发明。

translation: The invention of antibiotic was a magical thing.
transcript: 抗生素的发明是一个很神奇的事呃。

translation: It was not designed to treat any particular disease.
transcript: 因为它在那个时代，解决的不是某一种疾病。

translation: However, with the availability of antibiotic, we are able to treat literally almost all bacteria-infected diseases.
transcript: 啊因为有了抗生素，我们现在对于所有由细菌造成的疾病，基本上都没有什么问题了。

translation: Take a look at this picture.
transcript: 大家可以看到，在这张图的最右端。

translation: You can find out that when our average life span has reached nearly 80 years old, the curves then enter a platform period.
transcript: 啊就是当现在我们大家的平均寿命达到七八十岁的时候，这些曲线达到了一个平台期。

translation: In other words, how can we achieve a breakthrough as significant as the invention of antibiotics?
transcript: 那么下一步，如何再获得像抗生素发明时那样大的突破呢？

translation: From the point of view of scientists like me who study aging, we think that the next crucial step in increasing our average life span is through the application of anti-aging methods.
transcript: 站在我这样研究衰老的科学家的角度，就是我们认为，下一步你只有从抗衰老这个手段，啊才能够再一次有效地提高人类的那个平均寿命。

translation: Why is that so?
transcript: 那么为什么这样说呢？

translation: We might encounter many major diseases in our lives, such as cancers and cardiovascular diseases.
transcript: 我们一生中，会遇到很多严重的疾病，比如说癌症、心血管疾病。

translation: These diseases sound awful.
transcript: 这些疾病都很可怕。

translation: Would our average life span improve significantly as long as we have had ready cures for these diseases?
transcript: 哎那么是不是治愈其中一些疾病就可以大幅地提高我们的平均寿命？

translation: At the turn of this century, the US government did a hypothetical research—if all your diseases were cured overnight, what would happen next?
transcript: 呃在本世纪初，美国政府就做了一个这样的假设性研究，他们假设你在一夜之间，所有的某一些疾病都可以被治愈，那么会发生什么？

translation: For example, all your cancers were gone when you woke up in the morning, as if you had caught a cold.
transcript: 打个比方，所有的癌症在你明天早上醒来以后，就跟感冒一样。

translation: What would happen next?
transcript: 会怎么样？

translation: You might end up living 3.5 extra years.
transcript: 平均寿命可以延长大概三年半，只有三年半。

translation: Cardiovascular disease is now considered as the number one killer for our human being.
transcript: 然后作为现在人类第一杀手的心血管疾病。

translation: What would happen if it can be cured overnight?
transcript: 如果明天也跟感冒一样，会怎么样？

translation: You can live about 5 years longer, that’s it.
transcript: 平均寿命延长大约五年，仅此而已。

translation: In other words, it is very difficult to expect a sharp increase of average life span, say, an increase of 10 to 20 years, after we have developed a cure for a singular disease.
transcript: 它很难，就是说治愈这种单一疾病，很难再让我们的平均寿命出现10年20年这样子的飞跃。

translation: The significance is different from the invention of antibiotics.
transcript: 它不跟抗生素发明是完全不一样的。

translation: What’s more, curing a disease is technically difficult.
transcript: 但治愈这些疾病本身，其实是很难的。

translation: Why?
transcript: 这是为什么呢？

translation: The reason is rather simple.
transcript: 原因很简单。

translation: When you are getting older, you will eventually have either this disease or other diseases, and the fact is very sad.
transcript: 就是当你年纪大了以后，你不得这种病，就会去得那种病，就是这样子一个很可悲的现实。

translation: So we believe that anti-aging approach might be the most effective one.
transcript: 所以说我们认为啊抗衰老，应该是一种最有效的手段。

translation: Why do we have the courage to say so?
transcript: 那么我们为什么敢这样说呢？

translation: It is because of our research findings.
transcript: 是因为我们发现这些所有现在的重大疾病。

translation: We notice that the fatality rate and morbidity rate of those major diseases, including those diseases caused by bacterial infections in the past, are closely related to your age.
transcript: 啊甚至于包括过去的那些细菌感染，它的致死率跟发病率都是跟你的年龄急切相关的。

translation: In fact, this is also consistent with our life experience, that is, the older the age, the more likely to get sick and go to the hospital.
transcript: 这一点其实也跟大家的生活经验是相符的，就是年纪越大，越容易得病，越容易去医院。

translation: This is what we think, all diseases are closely associated with old age or aging.
transcript: 那么我们的一种想法就是，既然所有的这些疾病都和你的年龄或者衰老有关。

translation: Therefore, if we can find ways to delay aging from its root cause, or reverse your aging process, then your chances of having these diseases will drop significantly.
transcript: 啊，那么如果我们从根本的源头去延缓你的衰老，或者有办法逆转你的衰老过程，那么你得这些病的概率就会统统下降。

translation: This is a bit like the moment when the antibiotic was first invented in the 1940s.
transcript: 这一点就有点像四五十年代发明抗生素的那一刻。

translation: Antibiotic was not meant to treat pneumonia alone, but all diseases caused by bacterial infections.
transcript: 因为那一刻它对抗的不单单是肺炎，它对抗的是所有的感染。

translation: We are doing exactly the same.
transcript: 那么我们现在也是一样的。

translation: We want to promote this anti-aging method, which is not meant to cure neurodegenerative disease or cancers, but all those diseases being listed here that elderly people are inclined to have.
transcript: 我们希望用这种方法，它对抗的不是单单的神经退行性疾病，不单单对抗癌症，而是对抗这张表上列出的所有这些老年人很容易得的病。

translation: What is our expectation when carrying out this research?
transcript: 那么在我们这个研究，我们所期望能够获得的是什么呢？

translation: You might have read the slide with the word “immortal” on it.
transcript: 刚才那些啊slide里面有写出一个很酷的叫做immortal就是永生。

translation: I believe that it is indeed a romantic dream to be immortal.
transcript: 啊但是这个我认为这个还是一个很美好的梦想。

translation: It is a distant dream, but not an impossible one.
transcript: 啊在近期我个人认为，这是一个十分遥远，但是你是可以梦想的一个东西。

translation: So in reality what do we want to achieve?
transcript: 那实际上来说，我们希望的是什么？

translation: At the top of this chart is the course of life of every ordinary person.
transcript: 在这张表的最上面，是我们一般人的生命历程。

translation: In the last 10 to 20 years, you might live in pain.
transcript: 在你人生的最后十几年、二十年里，你可能会苦于病痛。

translation: What we are trying to do, look at the line at the bottom of the chart, is to increase your life span and shorten the time that you have to battle with diseases.
transcript: 那么我们希望能够达到的，是这张表最下面的那一条线，就是我们可以提高你的寿命，同时啊我们把你的这个跟病痛斗争的时间缩得很短。

translation: This is not an impossible dream, and we have abundant evidences, be it on animals or on a human being, to prove that this method is viable.
transcript: 这个并不是梦想啊，这个是的确确实是在不管是动物，还是人群中，是有实证的。

translation: I will give you a brief introduction to the understanding of aging by modern biology.
transcript: 那么我们来讲一讲，啊我们现在的现代生物学对衰老到底了解到一个什么样的程度？

translation: First of all, I want to tell you that the wisdom of ancient Chinese still works today.
transcript: 首先我想说一下，就是我们古人的智慧。

translation: Ancient Chinese people valued the yin and yang balance, and something would go wrong if the balance had been broken.
transcript: 我们古人一直强调一个阴阳平衡的理论，就是说你什么东西都会在于一个平衡，什么东西出问题了就是因为这个平衡被打破了。

translation: It is a very simple, traditional theory, but it works well to aging.
transcript: 啊这个呃这个很朴素或者说很传统的理论，对于衰老仍旧是适用的。

translation: Of course, modern biology has added new meaning to this traditional theory.
transcript: 当然我们现代生物学赋予它新的含义。

translation: Some aging factors, that can be perceived and measured scientifically, do exist in our bodies.
transcript: 就是说在我们的体内，同时存在着一些确确实实可以被科学测量、感知的衰老因子。

translation: Naturally, our bodies will take counter-measures, and there has always been a working mechanism.
transcript: 当然同时的我们体内为了对抗这些东西，一直有一套很不错的机制。

translation: We can simply say that we also have the longevity factors, including DNA repair and the mechanism to remove junk proteins.
transcript: 我们可以简单地说它们是长寿因子，它们包括DNA修复啊，还有一些去除垃圾蛋白的一些机制。

translation: Unfortunately, when you are getting older, the aging factor side will inevitably increase, and the longevity factor side will inevitably weaken.
transcript: 但是我们说可惜的是，就是说随着你年龄的增长，随着衰老的进程，衰老因子这一侧，不可避免地啊增加了，而长寿因子这一侧，不可避免地削弱了。

translation: That's why everyone would become  old.
transcript: 这也是为什么每个人会变老。

translation: Why does the change happen?
transcript: 为什么会发生这样子的变化？

translation: These are the questions that need to be answered by our biology scientists.
transcript: 啊这才是我们生物学所需要去回答的问题。

translation: This was a theory that was first proposed in the 1950s.
transcript: 这是上世纪五十年代就开始提出的理论。

translation: It was based on the evolutionary point of view, and explained why there was such an imbalance in your body, and why you got older.
transcript: 从进化论的角度来说，为什么你的体内会发生这样的失衡，为什么你会变老？

translation: A classical theory was proposed at that time, which is still applicable now, suggesting that during tens of millions years’ evolution.
transcript: 一个那时候提出一个很经典的理论，今天依旧适用，就是说进化在我们几十亿年的十几几千万年的进化中。

translation: Your body’s most important concern is whether you, as an animal, can produce a healthy offspring at all.
transcript: 最关心的一点，是你这个动物能不能产生健康的后代。

translation: Evolution has a strong selective pressure on your body, before you are able to produce an offspring.
transcript: 所以说进化在你产生后代之前，对你的身体有着一个很强的选择性压力。

translation: However, after you have finished producing an offspring, the pressure is gone.
transcript: 而在你产完后代之后，进化对你就是一种放任的状态了。

translation: Let’s see an example.
transcript: 那我们打一个比方。

translation: Just like you are attending a class, prior to you having an offspring, there is always a teacher sitting in your classroom, keeping a close eye on every student’s homework.
transcript: 这就像呃学生上课，啊在你产后代之前，在你的教室里一直坐着一个老师，他监督着每一个学生的功课，不能让你瞎搞。

translation: But when you have produced your offspring, the teacher goes back home.
transcript: 但是当你产完后代之后，这个老师就回家下班了。

translation: And the classroom becomes what the right picture displays here, in other words, your body is in a chaotic state.
transcript: 然后教室就变成像这个右图所显示这样，就你的身体也就慢慢走向一个无序的过程。

translation: Many research findings, including mine, have suggested the same thing.
transcript: 包括我自己的研究在内也表明。

translation: Some well-behaving students in the first half of the class become bad students in the second half of the class; and for this reason you are getting older.
transcript: 很多很多时候你衰老的原因，就是因为在前半节的一些好学生，在后半节变成了坏学生，啊这样导致。

translation: If we make one step further, we need to explain the phenomenon of aging from the perspectives of genetic and molecular levels.
transcript: 那么再进一步，在基因和分子水平我们怎么来解释衰老这个现象？

translation: I will first talk about how we study aging.
transcript: 那么我们稍微先简单谈一谈我们是怎么研究衰老。

translation: We need a module to study aging, and normally we will use animals that appear on this chart to carry out aging related researches.
transcript: 研究衰老需要一个模型，现在一般就使用这张图上所表示实验的这些动物。

translation: The animal on the far left side is called nematode, which can only live for three weeks, and we human beings are on the far right side.
transcript: 呃最左边的是一个叫做线虫的动物，它活得很短只有三周，然后最右边就是我们呃大家自己。

translation: For those animals with a relatively short life span, we are able to obtain their life expectancy data.
transcript: 我们可以看到，对于那些活得比较短的动物，我们是可以获得寿命的数数据的。

translation: However, for those animals that live long, for example, our human beings with a possible life span of 80 years old.
transcript: 但对于那些活得很长的，像我们人这样子的动物，因为它的寿命现在长达八十年。

translation: It is difficult for us to be sure that one approach or theory works in increasing the life expectancy.
transcript: 我们很难确切地知道，某一种方法或者某一种理论，能不能确切地延长寿命。

translation: But we can know whether some measures are effective in relieving aging related symptoms.
transcript: 但是我们还是可以知道，这些方法能不能改善一些衰老相关的症状。

translation: So, through these model animals, especially the leftmost nematode.
transcript: 那么通过这些模式动物，尤其是最左边的这个线虫。

translation: We learned a piece of encouraging news that aging can be genetically regulated.
transcript: 我们知道了一点，很不错的消息，就是衰老是可以被基因调控的。

translation: You might feel the news insignificant, but you know in the 1960s there was a theory claiming that aging was a passive process, in other words, we human beings are unable to intervene in this process.
transcript: 大家可能觉得没有什么，因为在六七十年代，一直有一种理论认为衰老是一个被动的过程，所以你也是无法干预的。

translation: But now we know that aging is actually an active process.
transcript: 但现在我们知道，衰老其实是一个主动的过程。

translation: Because it's active in itself, you can intervene in it.
transcript: 那么因为它本身是主动的，所以你也就可以对它进行干预。

translation: In the 1990s, people finally discovered first signal routing line, which was a line formed by molecular genes.
transcript: 那么在上世纪九十年代，人们终于找到了第一条可以连成队列的一条信号通路。

translation: That was the insulin signal routing line.
transcript: 就是由分子基因构成的一条信号通路，就是胰岛素信号通路。

translation: In our research with the nematode, we noticed that once we had removed one mutant gene, the animal would live twice to three times of its original life span.
transcript: 那时候在线虫中发现，你只要把其中的一个基因突变掉，这个动物就可以活的寿命是原来的两倍到三倍。

translation: As for the insulin signal routing line, we don’t need to go further details, as the naming of these genes and principles of biology are rather complicated.
transcript: 那么这个信号通路简单来说，我们跳开复杂的那些基因的名字和生物学的原理。

translation: The simplest interpretation is that with this insulin signal routing line the animal is likely to have mild diabetes.
transcript: 最通俗的说法，就是让动物去得了一个轻微的糖尿病。

translation: You know, insulin is designed to reduce the concentration level of blood sugar.
transcript: 因为大家都知道，胰岛素其实就是呃是改进血糖的。

translation: With the availability of this insulin signal routing line, some rubbish in your body can be recycled and unnecessary metabolism in your body can be reduced.
transcript: 通过那个治疗通路产生了一系列呃让你的身体内的一些垃圾可以被循环，让你身体内一些不必要的代谢可以下降。

translation: By doing so, your body can reach an orderly and sustainable state.
transcript: 这样子的手段，来让身体达到一个有序，然后是可持续发展的这样一个状态。

translation: After the discovery of this signal routing line, in the past 3 decades, we have discovered more molecular structures that are involved in regulating the process of aging.
transcript: 那么在这条通路之后，到现在已经过去了二三十年，在这时间发现了许许多多的这种分子，它们都参与调控衰老这件事情。

translation: So, as I mentioned at the very beginning, all of these molecules, although they have formed a very complex network of molecules, can still be roughly divided into two categories.
transcript: 那么就像我一开始提到过的，这些所有分子尽管构成了一个很复杂的分子网络，但它们大致还是可以分成两类。

translation: Some of them are designed to accelerate the process of aging, while the others are designed to confront with these aging factors.
transcript: 啊它们有一些其实是促进你衰老的，啊还有一些分子，它们是用来对抗这些衰老因子。

translation: We have known the molecular mechanisms in our research, and therefore we hope that we can find a way to delay the process of aging.
transcript: 那么我们现在的研究，当知得悉了这些分子机制之后，我们所希望的，啊就像我们是逆我们衰老而行。

translation: In other words, when we are getting older, we can find a way to minimize the effect caused by aging factors and magnify the effect caused by longevity factors.
transcript: 就是希望我们可以在年纪大以后，减弱衰老因子这一块，而去促进长寿因子这一方面的。

translation: We believe that, by doing so, even you are in your old age, we might help you live longer, improve your health condition and avoid having a series of age-sensitive diseases.
transcript: 那么这样我们相信你在老年期，可以延长你的寿命，可以改善你的健康，可以预防那一些种种的疾病。

translation: Finally I will talk about the possible solutions to delaying the process of aging from the perspective of modern biology.
transcript: 最后我们就来谈一谈，就是说在现代生物学的看法中，我们怎么来延缓衰老。

translation: Simply put, you have to control your environmental factor and genetic factor, that is, internal and external causes.
transcript: 简单来说就是你要控制好你的环境因素和遗传因素，也就是内因和外因。

translation: The environmental factor is easy to understand, as you need to find a nice place to live, and should not live in a hazy city.
transcript: 那么环境因素啊其实很简单，啊首先你要选一个好地方去生活，啊你不能生活在一个雾霾沉重的城市呃。

translation: It is not a joke anymore, and has been backed by scientific research findings.
transcript: 因为这个也这个已经不是笑话了，这个是有科学研究的。

translation: Two years ago the result of a cohort study was published.
transcript: 在前两年，他们发做过对于我国人群队列的研究。

translation: Researchers noticed that the average life span of people living in the north of the Huaihe River, a region with a serious air pollution problem, was 2 to 3 years shorter than that of people living in the south of the Huaihe River, a region with a better air quality.
transcript: 发现生活在淮河以北、空气污染比较严重的地区，他的平均寿命要比淮河以南、空气污染相对好一些那些地区，要短个两三年啊。

translation: Here is one more thing.
transcript: 那么同时这一点。

translation: Despite that it is irrelevant to any research findings, you should live in a place where you have access to high-quality medical services.
transcript: 其实跟我们这种科学研究没有什么关系，就是你要生活在一个医疗保障很不错的地方。

translation: Actually it is universally true.
transcript: 呃这一点其实是在全世界都被证明了。

translation: If you want to live longer, you should rather live a place that is near a major hospital but not a remote island with a beautiful view.
transcript: 就是说你要活得长，不是要生活在一个风景秀丽的海岛上，而是应该生活在一家大医院的隔壁。

translation: Apart from having this done, what shall we do to live a longer life?
transcript: 那么在做到这一点以后，那我们自己还能干什么？

translation: The first method, which you might have already heard of, is called diet control.
transcript: 呃第一种方法，其实大家以前应该都听说过，就是所谓的限制饮食。

translation: In other words, you need to eat less, so that you can live longer and healthier.
transcript: 也就是所谓的吃得少，你就可以活得长，活得健康。

translation: This method is not merely a voice of experience, but has been proved so by scientific research findings.
transcript: 这个并不是一个我们说一个经验之谈，而是确确实实有大量的科学实验证明。

translation: Well, from the simplest nematode, saccharomycetes to primates, such as macaques, an observable phenomenon has occurred.
transcript: 呃从最简单的线虫、酵母，一直到现在已经做到灵长类，也就是猕猴，都有同样的现象。

translation: That is, when an animal enters a state of dieting, it can live longer and healthier.
transcript: 就说这个动物，如果进入一种节食的状态，它都可以活得更长，而且可以活得更健康。

translation: Look at the monkeys in the picture on your right.
transcript: 就像这个右边的这些猴子的照片。

translation: Monkeys, like our human beings, will lose their hair when they are older.
transcript: 猴子跟我们人一样，年纪大了会脱发掉毛。

translation: You can see that the monkey on a diet is very healthy, and the hair on the body is very shiny.
transcript: 你可以看到那个节食的猴子很健康，啊身上的毛发很有光泽。

translation: However, for monkeys, at about the same age and without having any diet, you can tell that their hair is almost gone, and they might live much shorter.
transcript: 而那个同样年龄的没有节食的那些猴子，你可以看到它的身上的那个毛都掉得差不多了都，但它们也会活得短一些。

translation: But the real dieting is not the so-called concept of “70% fullness of stomach appearing in the newspapers and magazines.
transcript: 但是这个节食，并不是大家平时在那个报刊杂志上，看到的所谓的七分饱的那个概念。

translation: The real dieting is much harder to endure than the 70% fullness of stomach.
transcript: 节食远远要比这个七分饱要苛刻。

translation: The concept of 70% fullness of stomach only meets the dietary standards recommended by nutritionists, but the real dieting will require you to cut a further 30%.
transcript: 可以这样说七分饱的概念，只是让你达到呃我们说一个正常的，就是营养学推荐的那种饮食标准，节食要求你在这个基础上再少吃30%。

translation: Generally speaking, under such a circumstance, everyone will feel a strong sense of hunger, which will make you become moody.
transcript: 一般正常人哦，在这种情况下，每个人都会有强烈的饥饿感，因为这些饥饿感会导致坏心情。

translation: I don’t know what other people think, but I will definitely feel very bad.
transcript: 我不知道大家怎么想，但我的心情肯定会很坏。

translation: Nutrition issues will arise.
transcript: 因为此因为这个营养可能有一些问题。

translation: You’re more likely to feel exhausted.
transcript: 所以你的身体更容易疲劳。

translation: Your cognitive function and your mental and psychological well-being are deteriorating.
transcript: 啊认知功能，不管是心理的，还是生理的，都会有一些减退。

translation: It is indeed very hard to endure the pain of dieting.
transcript: 所以这是很难实行的。

translation: Then we come up with a new idea.
transcript: 那么我们就想一种办法。

translation: If we can’t eat less, can we change our dietary structure?
transcript: 如果不能够完全吃得少，那能不能改变一下食谱的结构呢？

translation: I mean to eat more healthy foods and consume less harmful foods.
transcript: 就是我把一些有益的东西多吃一点，有害的东西少吃一点。

translation: Let’s return back to the insulin signal routing line.
transcript: 那么这个我们回到刚才说到的胰岛素信号通路。

translation: Insulin is designed to regulate the blood sugar level.
transcript: 胰岛素是感受血糖的。

translation: Ms. Cynthia Kenyon, the person who first discovered insulin signal routing line, suggests a solution, saying that maybe we can reduce our sugar intake and manually reduce the blood sugar level.
transcript: 所以说科学家们呃，包括这位这位女士是发现这个胰岛素信号通路的先驱，呃Cynthia Kenyon女士，她想出一个方案，就是说针对胰岛素通路，我们少吃一点糖，要人为地降低你的血糖水平。

translation: She suggests that you should eat more vegetables and fruit, but don't eat vegetables and fruits that contain a lot of sugar, like watermelon.
transcript: 她说你应该多吃蔬菜、水果，但不要吃那些含糖量很高的，像西瓜这样子的蔬菜水果。

translation: It is OK for you to eat meat and fish.
transcript: 啊她说你可以吃肉，没有问题的，吃鱼，吃荤菜都没有问题。

translation: She also marked this line in red.
transcript: 但是她就是下面用红字标出了这一行。

translation: I bet you must can read it clearly.
transcript: 我想大家可能应该也看得懂。

translation: She suggested that we should not eat potato, spaghetti and flour-made dishes, as flour-made dishes are the biggest sources of blood sugar in our body.
transcript: 她说不要吃土豆，不要吃意大利面，不要吃面食，因为面食其实是我们体内糖的最大的来源。

translation: This theory is totally different from the theory that you have heard many times at TV programs, suggesting that you should have more coarse grains and eat less meat.
transcript: 啊这一点和大家同样的，从很多节目中看到那种，吃粗粮，呃少吃肉，少吃油腻，这样子可以活得怎么怎么样的理念，是完全背道而驰。

translation: Ms. Cynthia Kenyon is now following this recipe.
transcript: 呃她本人现在在身体力行这个食谱。

translation: This scientist is not a woman of words, and she is actually following this recipe.
transcript: 呃这位科学家并不是只做不说的哦只说不做的，她是既做又说的。

translation: We will wait and see the outcome of her experiment.
transcript: 呃至于怎么样，我们可以期待的。

translation: But some recent studies of nutrition did agree with her method, saying that this method seemed extreme but made sense.
transcript: 但是近来的一些营养学的研究的确也表明，她的这个建议，尽管有一些极端，但的确也是有道理的。

translation: Our previous nutritional guidelines, suggesting eating more coarse grains and vegetable and eating less meat, might be wrong.
transcript: 啊我们过去的那些营养指针，呃就是指导大家多吃粗粮，或者说是多吃蔬菜，少吃肉类，很有可能是有问题的。

translation: With the advancement of further researches, some scientists suggest that you might take a particular pill each day and you will then stay healthy.
transcript: 那么当然随着现在的研究，已经提出一些药物，你以后可能通过吃一些每天吃一粒药片，你就可以怎么怎么样。

translation: As for the pills, the most famous one is metformin, which was originally a drug used to treat diabetes.
transcript: 然后这个药片，最有名这个药就是二甲双胍，它原本是一个用来治疗糖尿病的药。

translation: The design concept of this drug is closely linked to the insulin signal routing line.
transcript: 啊这个药其实跟那个胰岛素通路也是有关系的，在分子机理上，也正是通过胰岛素通路来解释的。

translation: The drug was approved into clinical practice by the US FDA two years ago.
transcript: 这个药在两年前，已经被美国FDA批准进入临床实践。

translation: The purpose for this clinical trial is not to see how it works against diabetes.
transcript: 这次临床实践，不是为了看它对抗糖尿病的作用。

translation: But its role in reducing the incidence rate for people in having cancer, cardiovascular disease, and neurodegenerative diseases.
transcript: 就是为了看它能不能在人群中降低像癌症、心血管疾病、神经退行性疾病，这些疾病的发病率。

translation: Also, I would like to emphasize that the current anti-aging research has never set increase of life expectancy as a key target, to me it is unscientific.
transcript: 同样我还想再强调一下，现在的抗衰老研究，从来没有以提高寿命为指标，呀因为这个其实是不科学的啊。

translation: Apart from taking these experimental drugs, there is another possible solution to help us live longer and this solution is much easier to be accepted by us.
transcript: 除了这种试验性的药物，其实对于每一个人来说，都有一种更容易啊更更容易接受的。

translation: It is to do moderate-level physical exercise, and by doing so you can produce the appropriate amount of peroxides in your body, let your body get a moderate oxidative damage.
transcript: 就是你应该进行适度的体育锻炼，可以让你体内产生适量的过氧化物，就让你的体内得到一种适度的氧化损伤。

translation: It is a metaphor.
transcript: 这是这打个比方。

translation: You are getting older, and your body will eventually meet a very strong oxidative damage.
transcript: 就是你年纪大了，你的身体最终是要面对很强的氧化损伤。

translation: However,  when you do physical exercises regularly, as if your body keeps preparing for mock exams, your body will handle the big test with ease, right?
transcript: 那么你通过平时的体育锻炼，让你的身体就像学生准备模拟考试一样的，多考两次模拟考，这样到大考的时候就不会慌了对吧。

translation: Basically it is so.
transcript: 简单来说就是这样这个原理。

translation: But I want to stress that it is a sort of moderate-level physical exercise.
transcript: 但是同时我们这也十分强调，适度的体育锻炼。

translation: When the physical exercise is intense and beyond the limit of your physical condition, it will produce excessive oxygen compounds, causing excessive damage to your body.
transcript: 因为如果是强度十分大的，完全超出你负荷这样子强度的体育锻炼，它其实会产生太多的过氧化合物，对你身体造成过量的损伤，呃。

translation: I will add a new point here, only a personal opinion.
transcript: 在这边稍微说一句题外话，这只是我个人的观点哦。

translation: I never recommend people to run a marathon or do such sports like that.
transcript: 我从来不推荐马拉松这样子的运动。

translation: I feel that people who run marathons every year are people who have trouble with themselves.
transcript: 我一直觉得，每年去跑马拉松的人都是在跟自己过不去的。

translation: Of course in the recent two years, there are more innovative ideas being proposed, and these ideas are totally different from the previous aging-factor knowledge.
transcript: 当然这最近两年，还有一些我们说别辟蹊径的方法，它完全脱离过去对于衰老的这些分子信号的认识。

translation: One of the simplest innovative ideas is that when you are getting older, more and more cells in your body will enter an aging state.
transcript: 它一个最简单的办法，它说，因为你年纪大了，你的体内有很多细胞会进入衰老状态。

translation: And these aging cells actually produce some very bad reactions like inflammation.
transcript: 而这些衰老的细胞，其实会产生像炎症这样子的一些很不好的反应。

translation: Then scientists come up with the idea of eliminating these aging cells.
transcript: 那么就有科学家想到，要不就干脆把这些衰老细胞提前干掉。

translation: As a result, the concentration level of aging cells will remain at a low level.
transcript: 让你体内的衰老细胞数降到最低。

translation: The solution is indeed innovative, and the result has been proved by researches on experimental white rats.
transcript: 啊这是一种别辟蹊径的方法，它也是可以，至少在小鼠中是被证明是有一定的效果的。

translation: Yes, as long as we eliminate aging cells, we can find a way to combat aging.
transcript: 所以说我们说去除老化细胞，然后也可以对抗衰老。

translation: We hope that, by carrying out our research, we can help more people, in their 80, 90 or 100 of age, to stay active and young as these two people standing in front of us, and their old-age life can still be colorful.
transcript: 啊我们希望通过我们的研究，希望大多数人，在他们的80岁90岁，甚至100岁的时候，也可以像这两位一样，啊十分的活跃，然后十分的生活仍旧是十分的多姿多彩。

translation: Thank you.
transcript: 谢谢大家。
